section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we make things go?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Judith Koppens Illustrated by Eline van Lindenhuizen
section-block.rac_book_summary: Giraffe wants to play with his animal friends on the seesaw, but he is bigger than them! Read how Giraffe works with his friends to play on the seesaw and notice measurements and numbers as you read.

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65100-3. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Seesaw by Judith Koppens, illustrated by Eline van Lindenhuizen. Copyright © 2013 by Clavis Publishing Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Clavis Publishing Inc.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_body-text: Introduce measurement tools that you have in your classroom: balance scale, ruler, measuring cups, blocks, paper clips, etc. and use them to measure long items.
Ask children which of two items is taller. Line up the objects to compare. Develop measurement vocabulary by encouraging children to use smaller and taller.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Seesaw by Judith Koppens and illustrated by Eline van Lindenhuizen.
You know that Lala the Lizard loves all sorts of books. Lala loves books that help us understand measuring, like this book does!
Think about this question, and we’ll talk about it after we read:

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement As you read and ask questions, help children compare the weights of the animals.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Giraffe want do at the playground? Have you been on a seesaw? How does it work? (MB)
Why can’t Giraffe go on the seesaw alone? What will happen if he sits on the seesaw by himself?
What will happen if Mouse sits on the other side of the seesaw?
What happened when Mouse sat? Why was Giraffe lower?
Mouse says that Monkey is heavier. Who weighs more: Monkey or Mouse?
Now Dog tries. Why can’t Giraffe get the seesaw to go up?
Mouse, Monkey, and Dog devise a plan. That means they think of an idea to help Giraffe. What do you think the plan will be?
It looks like Giraffe is on one side and Monkey, Mouse, and Dog are on the other side. What happened? Why are they able to seesaw now?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Monkey and Dog go on the seesaw.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about measuring the weight of people or animals.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who does Mouse try to go on the seesaw with?
Mouse tries to go on the seesaw with G________ (Giraffe).
Mouse tries to go on the seesaw with Giraffe.
How do the animals use the seesaw together?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Encourage children to use playtime to reinforce measurement concepts. Experiment on the seesaw by asking different children to try to balance it. Encourage children to make predictions before the children sit on the seesaw. Guide children to compare their predictions to the outcome. Ask them to share their conclusions with the group.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Work Together
section-block.rac_body-text: Working together means sharing tasks with others to achieve a common goal. Point out to children that you can learn about working together through playing games or working on projects with friends. Part of building this skill is learning to ask other children to play or ask to join a group that is already playing.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread The Seesaw by Judith Koppens and illustrated by Eline van Lindenhuizen to look closer at some parts of the book. We will think about how to work together towards a goal.
Clifford loves the way the animals in this story work together to make a plan so that Giraffe can play on the seesaw.

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement Point out opportunities to compare the animals by weight and height.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is Giraffe’s goal on the playground? (MB)
Can you play on a seesaw alone? What does Giraffe need to play on the seesaw? (MB)
What happens when Mouse gets on the seesaw? Who weighs more, Mouse or Giraffe? Who is taller? Did Giraffe reach his goal of playing on the seesaw? (MB)
Who do you think weighs more, Monkey or Dog? Who is taller? Who do you think weighs more, Dog or Giraffe?
Working together can help us meet a goal. How do Mouse, Monkey, and Dog work together? How did working together help the animals meet their goal of playing on the seesaw? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Play We’re Going on a Trip with children. Have children pretend to be a scale. In one hand, they will pretend to hold a heavy suitcase. In the other hand, they will pretend to carry an item that they want to bring on the trip.

Go around the circle. Have each child announce what they are bringing in turn by saying, We’re going on a trip, and I’m taking a ___ . Have children pretend to put these items in their other hands. They should show which is heavier, the suitcase or the item, by leaning in the direction of the heavier object.
Transcribe children’s speech as they tell about playing on the playground.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children are transitioning from playing alone or in parallel to engaging with others. Model for children how to join a group by helping them through the process. Ask the question for them, “Can I play, too?” Remind them what the group’s goal is so they can adopt the same goal in their play. (LeBlanc/OCW.UMB.edu, 1989)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_body-text: Adding or taking away one changes the quantity of a set by one. Show how to add or take away one with animal finger puppets or snap cubes.
Sing part of “The Ants Go Marching” and part of “Five Green and Speckled Frogs” with children. Have them use their fingers to count up and down as you sing.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread The Seesaw by Judith Koppens and illustrated by Eline van Lindenhuizen.
Lala loves reading narratives that tell stories, like this one.
Comparing measurements or numbers tells whether something is more or less, higher or lower, and heavier or lighter. As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does the seesaw show which side weighs more?

section.rac_body-text: As you read, point out pages on which one animal joins or gets off the seesaw, and how that changes the total number of animals by one.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many animals are on the seesaw before Mouse joins? How many are on the seesaw after?
What happens when Mouse and Giraffe are both on the seesaw? Which side weighs more?
How many are on the seesaw when Mouse climbs off? How does that number change when Monkey jumps on?
What happens when Monkey is on the seesaw? Which side weighs less? How do you know?
How many animals are on the seesaw? Let’s count! How many animals are on after Dog comes?
How many animals did Giraffe need on the other side of the seesaw to make it work? What happens when Giraffe’s three friends sit on the other side?
Let’s discuss the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does the seesaw show which side weighs more?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The side that weighs more goes down.
The side that weighs less goes higher.
The seesaw works when both sides weigh almost the same.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about more and less.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does the side of the seesaw that weighs less go higher or lower?
The side that weighs less goes h________ (higher).
The side that weighs less goes higher.
Can you play on the seesaw if both sides are close in weight?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: PreK children can begin to understand that adding or taking away one item from a set changes the total by one. You can introduce card and board games like Go Fish or Chutes and Ladders to reinforce the concept of adding or taking away from a set.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_body-text: Review that adding or taking away one changes the total by one. Point out that the order items are counted in does not change the number of items being counted.
Have children sing “Row, Row, Row Your Boat.” Act out and explain the way rowing moves a boat forward. Discuss other options for verses, such as pedal your bike.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Great Big Enormous Yuca. It is a story about how many people it took to pull an enormous plant called a yuca from the ground.
Lala can’t wait to read this narrative to find out what happens to the yuca.
The Seesaw and The Great Big Enormous Yuca each focus on making things move. Let’s look for more connections as we read!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to the concept question:
How can we make things go?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Making It Move
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions and talk about counting.
Have children count the characters in different orders to show that the number will stay the same regardless of counting order.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: The old man pulled and pulled.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How many people are pulling the yuca? Why did the old man have to pull so much?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: The old woman pulled the old man.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The old man got help from one woman. How many people are pulling in all?
How many more people helped the old man and the woman? How many in all?
Now, how many creatures are pulling in all? What happens when everyone works together? (MB)
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: The enormous yuca finally came up!
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What makes the yuca enormous? Do you think it weighs a lot? Why?

section.rac_body-text: Give children arts and crafts materials to create a scene from the story. Ask children to show how many people and animals are pulling to get the enormous yuca out of the ground. Encourage children to use their imagination to show how enormous the yuca plant was!
Provide a writing prompt and feedback about how size affected movement in the story as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Using hand puppets or acting out the story might help children better understand the Big Chart poster. Demonstrate pulling, and count out the number of people using counters or your fingers. Encourage children to do the same. By promoting a physical understanding of terms and ideas, the concepts are more clearly illustrated for multilingual learners.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss the way objects move. Point out that a seesaw goes up and down. Ask about the movements of other playground equipment.
Sing about the equipment on the playground to the tune of “The Wheels on the Bus”: The seesaw goes up and down, the swings go back and forth, all through the day.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read The Seesaw one more time this week.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches information. Which is it?
We have learned about counting the animals and comparing their sizes. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What makes the seesaw go up and down?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time together, this time acting out parts of the story.
Are Giraffe and Mouse equal in size and weight?
What happens when the sides of a seesaw are not the same? Let’s use our arms to show seesaws where one side weighs less!
Mouses scrambles down to get off the seesaw quickly. Let’s pretend we are getting down fast from something that is tall!
Monkey leaps up onto the seesaw because it is up high. Let’s show how we would get onto something high.
Dog is bigger and stronger than Monkey. Do you think Dog is bigger than Giraffe? What will happen when Dog and Giraffe are both on the seesaw? Show me with your arms!
What happens on the seesaw when three animals sit on one side of the seesaw and Giraffe sits on the other side?
It looks like their weight is almost equal. Let’s pretend to be seesaws with equal weight on both sides.
Now let’s pretend to be the animals moving the seesaw up and down.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What makes the seesaw go up and down?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to respond to the guiding question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The animals’ weights balance the seesaw.
Jumping up and down makes the seesaw move.
One side goes down if it weighs more than the other side.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about working together to reach a goal and share.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does Giraffe’s side go down more?
Giraffe’s side goes down because it weighs m___ (more).
Giraffe’s side goes down because it weighs more.
What happens if you put two equal weights on the seesaw?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The more weight an object has, the more difficult it is to lift. The less weight an object has, the easier it is to lift. Use measurement tools such as balance scales to experiment with weight. Reinforce the use of terms more, less, and equal to. Add different amounts of items to each side of the scale to see changes in movement.
